objective: 1. Background/Overview of Issue • Provides a clear, detailed description of a current health-related or environmental issue • Description is detailed but lacks clarity
specific_objectives: Provides a clear, detailed description of a current health-related or environmental issue
Description is detailed but lacks clarity

section: module on: the Online Registration System
objective: 2. Problem Statement • Research problem is stated clearly • Research problem is in an appropriate form – an observation or question
specific_objectives: Research problem is in an appropriate form – an observation or question

section: module on: the Online Registration System
objective: 3. Research Objective • Objective of the research is linked to the issue • Objective of the research is realistic/feasible
specific_objectives: Objective of the research is linked to the issue
Objective of the research is realistic/feasible

section: module on: the Online Registration System
objective: 4. Methodology • Sample used is identified and clearly described • Data collection instrument is identified and clearly described • Method of data collection is identified and clearly described • Method of data collection is adequately justified • ONE limitation of data collection method clearly stated
specific_objectives: Method of data collection is identified
Method of data collection is adequately justified
ONE limitation of data collection method clearly stated

section: module on: the Online Registration System
objective: 5. Pre s e n t a t ion of D at a • Data is presented in an appropriate form using tables, graphs and charts • Data is presented in at least TWO forms • Form(s) used for presentation of data is correctly labelled • Data presented are accurate
specific_objectives: Pre s e n t a t ion of D at a
Data is presented in an appropriate form using tables, graphs
Data is presented in at least TWO forms
Form(s) used for presentation of data is correctly labelled

section: module on: the Online Registration System
objective: 6. Analysis and Interpretation of Data • Data is analyzed using appropriate calculations/statistics/themes • Data is summarized accurately • At least TWO statements of findings based on data presented • Findings are consistent with analyses
specific_objectives: Data is analyzed using appropriate calculations/statistics/themes
At least TWO statements of findings based on data presented

section: module on: the Online Registration System
objective: 7. Conclusion • Conclusion succinctly summarizes the project • Conclusion is logical and based on findings

section: module on: the Online Registration System
objective: 8. Recommendations • At least TWO recommendations proposed • Recommendations are realistic • Recommendations are informed by findings

section: module on: the Online Registration System
objective: 9. Reflection: Candidate states the following information: • TWO lessons learnt after undertaking the project. • ONE way in which the lesson learnt could be applied to his/her personal life. • ONE way in which the project could be improved. • ONE social impact and ONE economic impact the issue could have on his/her school or community if not rectified.
specific_objectives: Reflection: Candidate states the following information:
TWO lessons learnt after undertaking the project.
ONE way in which the lesson learnt could be applied to his/her personal life.
ONE way in which the project could be improved.
ONE economic impact the issue could have on his/her school or community if not rectified.

content: A: Combustion (1) B: Cellular Respiration (1) C: Death (1) water (1) – reactant oxygen (1) products sugars/glucose (1) An increase in sea surface temperature (1) results in an increase in the intensity of hurricanes (1). OR Sea surface temperature is directly (1) proportional (1) to the intensity of hurricanes. An increase in CO levels results in 2 global warming (1) which causes surface sea temperatures to rise (1) resulting in more intense hurricanes (1)
content_items: A: Combustion (1) B: Cellular Respiration (1) C: Death (1) water (1) – reactant oxygen (1) products sugars/glucose (1) An increase in sea surface temperature (1) results in an increase in the intensity of hurricanes (1). OR Sea surface temperature is directly (1) proportional (1) to the intensity of hurricanes. An increase in CO levels results in 2 global warming (1) which causes surface sea temperatures to rise (1) resulting in more intense hurricanes (1)

unit to: use more

content: Blood pressure is the force needed (1) to pump blood to all parts of the body (1) Systole: contractions of the heart chambers (1) Diastole: relaxation of the heart chambers (1) 120 – systole (1)  Lack of physical activity/exercise  Stress  Smoking/tobacco use  Abuse of alcohol  High cholesterol  Poor diet (high salt, high fat)  Obesity John’s diet is rich in saturated fats (1) and high in salt (1). These factors contribute to hardening of the walls of the arteries (1) in addition to plaque formation (1) thus resulting in high blood pressure. James, although he smokes, not eating meat means he has a lower risk of plaque formation (1) therefore, resulting in a lower blood pressure. John’s heart rate increases (1) and at the end of the exercise it does not return to its basal rate (1). James heart rate is consistently lower than John’s (1). The possibility of John developing heart disease (1) may explain why his heart did not return to its basal rate. John can change his diet (1) or begin an exercise program (1)
content_items: Blood pressure is the force needed (1) to pump blood to all parts of the body (1) Systole: contractions of the heart chambers (1) Diastole: relaxation of the heart chambers (1) 120 – systole (1)  Lack of physical activity/exercise  Stress  Smoking/tobacco use  Abuse of alcohol  High cholesterol  Poor diet (high salt, high fat)  Obesity John’s diet is rich in saturated fats (1)

high in salt (1). These factors contribute to hardening of the walls of the arteries (1) in addition to plaque formation (1) thus resulting in high blood pressure. James, although he smokes, not eating meat means he has a lower risk of plaque formation (1) therefore, resulting in a lower blood pressure. John’s heart rate increases (1)

at the end of the exercise it does not return to its basal rate (1). James heart rate is consistently lower than John’s (1). The possibility of John developing heart disease (1) may explain why his heart did not return to its basal rate. John can change his diet (1) or begin an exercise program (1)

content: Macronutrients: Carbohydrates, Fats, Proteins (Any 1) Micronutrients: Any one vitamin or mineral named Carbon, Hydrogen, Oxygen (Any 1) Any ground provision (sweet potato, eddo, yam) Any grain (oats, corn, barley, wheat, rice) Malnutrition is a state of health that occurs when there is a lack of balance in the diet caused either by a shortage of certain nutrients (1) or by eating too many nutrients (1). Benita has anorexia nervosa (1) Benny has bulimia nervosa (1).  Muscle loss and wastage(1) due to a lack of protein in the diet (1)  Lethargy (1) due to a lack of carbohydrates and fats in the diet (1)  Brittle bones (1) due to a lack of calcium (1)  Swelling in his hands and feet (1) due to a lack of protein/electrolyte imbalance (1)  Irregular heartbeat (1) due to insufficient electrolytes (1)  Mental alertness (1) as a result of a lack of vitamins and minerals in the diet (1)

Benita has anorexia nervosa (1) Benny has bulimia nervosa (1).  Muscle loss
wastage(1) due to a lack of protein in the diet (1)  Lethargy (1) due to a lack of carbohydrates
fats in the diet (1)  Brittle bones (1) due to a lack of calcium (1)  Swelling in his hands
feet (1) due to a lack of protein/electrolyte imbalance (1)  Irregular heartbeat (1) due to insufficient electrolytes (1)  Mental alertness (1) as a result of a lack of vitamins

content: At the equator of the cell/ at the middle of the cell (1) Chromosomes are duplicated (1) and are held together at a central point by a centromere (1) Sex linked Female 1, 8 or 14 Colour blindness, Haemophilia Because GMOs can be grown under extreme conditions(1), they may out compete native plants for resources (1) If farmers are not growing native plants, fewer viable seeds will be produced (1) for the growth of subsequent crops (1) Accept any other reasonable response. GMOs  Give a higher yield (1)  Are resistant to pests(1)  Can tolerate poor soil conditions (1)  Drought resistant(1)  Produce crops where ripening is delayed (1)  May provide tastier fruits and vegetables (1)

GMOs  Give a higher yield (1)  Are resistant to pests(1)  Can tolerate poor soil conditions (1)  Drought resistant(1)  Produce crops where ripening is delayed (1)  May provide tastier fruits

content: C a n c e r is the abnormal uncontrolled (1) division of cells (1) Prostate, Cervix, Breasts, Lung (Any 2) Surgical removal of growth/tumour (1) Radiation therapy to destroy the Tumour (1) Chemotherapy (1)  In Situation I, influenza is considered to be a pandemic disease (1) because it was spread over a wide geographic area/worldwide (1) and every time the disease is manifested, it is considered a new disease (1)  In Situation II, leptospirosis is considered to be an epidemic disease (1) because it was localised/spread over a small geographical area/neighbourhood (1) and there were an unusual number of cases that occurred at the same time (1)

every time the disease is manifested, it is considered a new disease (1)  In Situation II, leptospirosis is considered to be an epidemic disease (1) because it was localised/spread over a small geographical area/neighbourhood (1)
there were an unusual number of cases that occurred at the same time (1)

content: Landfills are lined (1) to prevent water contamination dumps are not lined (1). Landfills are covered with dirt (1) while dumps are found on the open ground (1). Landfills contain nonhazardous waste (1)while dumps are a mixture hazardous and nonhazardous waste (1). Landfills are controlled and highly regulated (1) while dumps are unregulated (1).  Contamination of ground water  Provides home for vectors  Produces an unpleasant smell  Produces carbon dioxide and methane gas which contribute to global warming Your proposal should include the following points:  The council could implement a new waste disposal policy which requires residents to sort their garbage at home into the categories of waste (1)  Recycling companies could be invited to collect the sorted waste (1) OR residents can place their sorted waste into appropriate recycling bins (1)  The council could impose fines for non-compliance with the new policy (1)  Recycling bins could be placed at various locations within the village to encourage the proper disposal of plastics, paper and metals(1)  Organic waste can be composted and the compost sold or used for fertilizing the village’s gardens/parks (1)
content_items: Landfills are lined (1) to prevent water contamination dumps are not lined (1). Landfills are covered with dirt (1) while dumps are found on the open ground (1). Landfills contain nonhazardous waste (1)while dumps are a mixture hazardous
highly regulated (1) while dumps are unregulated (1).  Contamination of ground water  Provides home for vectors  Produces an unpleasant smell  Produces carbon dioxide

methane gas which contribute to global warming Your proposal should include the following points:  The council could implement a new waste disposal policy which requires residents to sort their garbage at home into the categories of waste (1)  Recycling companies could be invited to collect the sorted waste (1) OR residents can place their sorted waste into appropriate recycling bins (1)  The council could impose fines for non-compliance with the new policy (1)  Recycling bins could be placed at various locations within the village to encourage the proper disposal of plastics, paper
metals(1)  Organic waste can be composted
the compost sold or used for fertilizing the village’s gardens/parks (1)
